sub_topic: Calculating the magnetic moment of inorganic compounds.
message_1: What is the magnetic moment of a compound with the following configuration: [Fe(H2O)6]3+?
message_2:
To determine the magnetic moment of the [Fe(H2O)6]3+ complex, we first need to find the number of unpaired electrons in the Fe3+ ion.

The electron configuration of Fe (iron) is [Ar] 3d^6 4s^2. When it forms the Fe3+ ion, it loses 3 electrons, 2 from the 4s orbital and 1 from the 3d orbital. The electron configuration of Fe3+ is [Ar] 3d^5.

Now, we can use the spin-only formula to calculate the magnetic moment (µ):

µ = √(n(n+2)) µB

where n is the number of unpaired electrons and µB is the Bohr magneton (approximately 9.27 x 10^-24 Am²).

In the case of Fe3+ with 5 unpaired electrons:

µ = √(5(5+2)) µB
µ = √(5(7)) µB
µ = √35 µB

The magnetic moment of the [Fe(H2O)6]3+ complex is approximately √35 µB (around 5.92 µB).
